title: Jackie Stewart talks about wife Helen's battle with Dementia and charity Race Against Dementia
text:
Formula One legend Sir Jackie Stewart has revealed the devastating toll dementia has taken on his wife.

Sir Jackie, 80, had his world turned upside down when his wife Lady Helen was diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia in 2016.

Two years ago he started a charity called Race Against Dementia in a bid to find a cure for the disease and use innovative racing technology to speed up the process.

Appearing on Good Morning Britain from his home in Geneva he detailed the 'pain' dementia has brought to his wife and the rest of his family.

He told the programme: 'To see her going through the pain of dementia, that affecting our whole family. I feel we have to change that. We have to move forward.'

Asked what is the worst part of the disease, he said Lady Helen is no longer able to walk.

He said: 'I think the memory thing is the least of it, but walking is no longer possible. Memory is something we can handle.'

The Scotsman previously said his wife, whom he married 57 years ago, receives 24-hour care and still enjoys being 'cuddled and kissed' but fears that even her long-term memory of their time together will soon disappear.

Sir Jackie has also described his wife's dementia as 'the greatest challenge of my life'.

The racing driver, who won the F1 world championship three times, said caring for a dementia patient is twice as expensive as caring for someone with cancer.

He said: 'In these past 30 years, however much has been put into it, there are no cures.

Sir Jackie (pictured live today from his home in Geneva), 80, had his world turned upside down when his wife Lady Helen was diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia in 2016

'Even in the NHS in our country and the UK, you don't have enough money to be able to care for them, in hospitals and in homes. We have a major problem with it.'

Sir Jackie revealed he is investing £3.75million into funding five PHD students looking into dementia care.

He said: 'I truly believe there are no problems, only solutions.

'We have great skills in the UK and around the world – it's a global problem. But we're going to have to move forward faster than we have in the past.'

Helen was first diagnosed three years ago after she couldn't remember how a car accident happened in the grounds of the couple's lavish Chiltern Hills estate.

Now based full-time in Geneva, Lady Helen is cared for around the clock by a team of eight neuroscience nurses and the four-storey house the couple share on the banks of Lake Geneva has been kitted out with state-of-the-art technology.
